content.description: Climb a hard crack on the orange prow. The crux is an uncomfortable flared groove that is protected by two bolts.
content.protection: 2 each of .2-1 cams. Nuts help for the beginning.

climbs.name: Turning Point
climbs.fa: Don Spittler, David Babich, 1976  FFA: Eric Barrett, George Conner, 1978

content.description: Stemming, finger cracks, stemming, laybacks, stemming, and jams. All thoughtful, mostly on gorgeous granite with golden glacial polish. Good stances below crux moves, which come more or less every roof, depending on your stylistic strengths.
content.protection:
Pro to 3.5", doubles of 0.5-2".

There is now a 2 bolt anchor with chains at the top of this route. I was able to rap easily with a 70 m rope, but not sure if a 60 m would make it.

Also, it looks like whoever put the chains up tried to grind down the welds on the links a bit, which left some very sharp burrs on the inside of the links. If you don't notice this and just haphazardly thread your rope through, you could easily shred your sheath. Be careful, or maybe bring a file.
content.location: Southwest face, right side, corner series of right facing broken roofs.

content.description:
Scrubby's Crossing follows the line of weakness through the attractive black, white, and golden granite face on the right side of the Lost John formation.

Climb easily up cracks on the left face placing a piece or two of gear to reach the first bolt. The line then steps right and underclings the orange and black feature as it turns vertical and heads towards the small triangular roof. The distinct crux between the third and fourth bolts rewards crafty granite footwork and leads to quality moves up the crack to the anchor. Packs a lot of quality and difficult moves into 40 feet!
content.protection: A piece or two of gear for the start and 8 bolts. Coldshut anchor.
